item.title: 3D Rasterizer
item.description: 3D Rasterizer in Python October 2020 Task Description: For my Introduction to Computer Graphics class at the University of Virginia, I created a 3D rasterizer that implements the pipeline for rasterizing triangles. Features: Transformations (model/view, projection, rotation, translation, scaling, and lookat) Per-pixel clipping - pixels with a z-value less than 0 or greater than 1 are not drawn Depth buffer check Implements DDA algorithm for drawing lines Supports sun lights coming from a specified direction Allows an arbitrary number of lights and sums their contributions Uses Lambert’s Law for illumination Improvements:

item.title: Animation
item.description: Animation 1. Animated Short Film: “Monsoon” December 2019 VIEW PROJECT VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS University of Virginia ARCH 5420 Final Project Description: I created a 1-3 minute animation incorporating themes from the entire semester (time, light, etc.). Features and Responsibilities: Modeled, shaded, rigged, and animated all characters and settings (with the exception of the gate and power line - courtesy of TurboSquid) MEL scripting to manipulate the rain, wind, and light intensity Rendered over 3,500 frames in V-Ray using multiple computers Features V-Ray Mesh Lighting and Environmental Fog Improvements:

item.title: Mini Maya
item.description: Mini Maya with Processing and Arduino May 2020 VIEW PROJECT VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS University of Virginia ARCH 5424 Final Project Description: I created a Processing and Arduino project incorporating concepts from the entire semester, including cinematography, computer vision, and microcontrollers. Features and Responsiblities: Built a “mini Maya” 3D modeling and rendering program with Processing Supports basic primitives, scaling, rotating, translating, and camera movement Includes a pre-loaded animation when “play” button is pressed Renders out frames to separate “data” folder in the current directory While rendering, displays status on external LCD monitor (Processing sends signals to Arduino program) Improvements:

item.title: Monte Carlo Path Tracer
item.description: Monte Carlo Path Tracer in C++ November 2020 Utah Teapot (50 samples) Description: For my final project in Introduction to Computer Graphics at the University of Virginia, I extended a ray tracer I wrote into a unidirectional path tracer. I translated my original Python implementation into C++ for improved performance. Features: Monte Carlo sampling for global illumination Sampling of area lights (produces soft shadows) Color bleeding Gamma correction Ray-sphere, triangle, plane, and rectangle intersections Diffuse, reflective, and refractive materials Improvements:
